sen.j: 吉良 義藤（きら よしふじ、生没年不詳）は室町時代の武将。
sen.e: Yoshifuji KIRA (dates of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Muromachi period.
Yoshifuji KIRA (dates of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Muromachi period.
Yoshifuji KIRA (dates of birth and death unknown) was a busho (Japanese military commander) in the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 吉良持助の子。
sen.e: He was a son of Mochisuke KIRA.
He was a son of Mochisuke KIRA.
He was a son of Mochisuke KIRA.

sen.j: 東条城主。
sen.e: He was a head of Tojo-jo Castle.
He was a head of Tojo-jo Castle.
He was a head of Tojo-jo Castle.

sen.j: 後期東条吉良氏（下吉良）5代目。
sen.e: He was the fifth head of the latter Tojokira clan (Shimokira).
He was the fifth head of the latter Tojokira clan (Shimokira).
He was the fifth head of the latter Tojokira clan (Shimokira).

sen.j: 右兵衛佐、右兵衛督と称す。
sen.e: He took the position of Uhyoe no suke (assistant captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) and Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards).
He took the position of Uhyoe no suke (assistant captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) and Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards).
He took the position of Uhyoe no suke (assistant captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) and Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards).

sen.j: 弟はいずれも僧籍に入った等康、端東。
sen.e: His brothers were Toshiyasu and Tadato and both of them entered the Buddhist priesthood.
His brothers were Toshiyasu and Tadato and both of them entered the Buddhist priesthood.
His brothers were Toshiyasu and Tadato and both of them entered the Buddhist priesthood.

sen.j: 妻は山名宗全の娘。
sen.e: His wife was a daughter of Sozen YMAMNA.
His wife was a daughter of Sozen YAMANA.
sen.cmt: スペルミスがあります。
sen.e: His wife was a daughter of Sozen YAMANA.

sen.j: 子は吉良持清。
sen.e: His son was Mochikiyo KIRA.
His son was Mochikiyo KIRA.
His son was Mochikiyo KIRA.

sen.j: 長禄3年（1459年）12月15日、室町幕府が足利義持の33回忌法要を営むため、諸大名に銭の献納を求めた際、義藤は10貫文を献上している（『蔭凉軒日録』）。
sen.e: In January 17, 1460, when Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) held a Buddhist memorial service for the thirty-two anniversary of Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA's death and asked daimyo (feudal lords) for donation, Yoshifuji offered 10 kanmon (1,000 kanmon=10,000 yen) ("Inryoken Nichiroku"[Dietary Life of Zen Priests]).

In January 17, 1460, when Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) held a Buddhist memorial service for the thirty-two anniversary of Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA's death and asked daimyo (feudal lords) for donation, Yoshifuji offered 10 kanmon (1,000 kanmon=10,000 yen) ("Inryoken Nichiroku"[Dietary Life of Zen Priests]).

In January 17, 1460, when Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) held a Buddhist memorial service for the thirty-two anniversary of Yoshimochi ASHIKAGA's death and asked daimyo (feudal lords) for donation, Yoshifuji offered 10 kanmon (1,000 kanmon=10,000 yen) ("Inryoken Nichiroku"[Dietary Life of Zen Priests]).

sen.j: 寛正6年（1465年）5月、三河国額田郡南部の幕府奉公衆の一族及び足利氏下級被官層が蜂起し、東海道の要所井口（愛知県岡崎市）に砦を構えた。
sen.e: In June 1465, the family of bakufu-hoko-shu (servants for bakufu) in the south of Nukata-gun, Mikawa Province and hikan (bureaucrats in lower class) of the Ashikaga clan rose in revolt and built their fortress in a key position of Tokai-do Road, Iguchi (Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In June 1465, the family of bakufu-hoko-shu (servants for bakufu) in the south of Nukata-gun, Mikawa Province and hikan (bureaucrats in lower class) of the Ashikaga clan rose in revolt and built their fortress in a key position of Tokai-do Road, Iguchi (Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture).

In June 1465, the family of bakufu-hoko-shu (servants for bakufu) in the south of Nukata-gun, Mikawa Province and hikan (bureaucrats in lower class) of the Ashikaga clan rose in revolt and built their fortress in a key position of Tokai-do Road, Iguchi (Okazaki City, Aichi Prefecture).

sen.j: そして、鎌倉公方の下知と称して京都に運ばれる年貢などを掠奪する事件が起こる（額田郡一揆）。
sen.e: They plundered tribute rice being carried to Kyoto pretending that they had a command from Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kanto region) (uprising in Nukata-gun).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They plundered tribute rice being carried to Kyoto pretending that they had a command from Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kanto region) (uprising in Nukata-gun).
They plundered tribute rice being carried to Kyoto pretending that they had a command from Kamakura kubo (Governor-general of the Kanto region) (uprising in Nukata-gun).

sen.j: 最終的に一揆の首謀者らは幕府政所執事伊勢貞親の被官である松平信光・戸田宗光の軍によって討たれ、一揆は平定された。
sen.e: In the end, the army of Nobumitsu MATSUDAIRA and Munemitsu TODA, hikan (bureaucrats) for Sadachika ISE, a steward of the Bakufu Mandokoro defeated the ringleaders of the uprising and conquered it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the end, the army of Nobumitsu MATSUDAIRA and Munemitsu TODA, hikan (bureaucrats) for Sadachika ISE, a steward of the Bakufu Mandokoro defeated the ringleaders of the uprising and conquered it.
In the end, the army of Nobumitsu MATSUDAIRA and Munemitsu TODA, hikan (bureaucrats) for Sadachika ISE, a steward of the Bakufu Mandokoro defeated the ringleaders of the uprising and conquered it.

sen.j: しかし、後期東条吉良氏（下吉良）は義藤の祖父吉良持長が鎌倉公方足利持氏との関係を噂され結城合戦後に出奔したことからもわかるように、伝統的に親鎌倉府の立場を採っていた。
sen.e: However, Yoshifuji's grandfather, Mochinaga KIRA ran away after Yuki War, because there was a rumor that he was close to Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, Kamakura Kubo, which showed that the latter Tojokira clan traditionally sided with Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, Yoshifuji's grandfather, Mochinaga KIRA ran away after Yuki War, because there was a rumor that he was close to Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, Kamakura Kubo, which showed that the latter Tojokira clan traditionally sided with the Kamakura Government (a regional government installed in Kamakura by the Ashikaga Shogunate but the relationship between the Ashikaga Shogunate and this regional government deteriorated later).
sen.cmt: 「鎌倉府」は『鎌倉幕府」ではありません。
sen.e: However, Yoshifuji's grandfather, Mochinaga KIRA ran away after Yuki War, because there was a rumor that he was close to Mochiuji ASHIKAGA, Kamakura Kubo, which showed that the latter Tojokira clan traditionally sided with the Kamakura Government (a regional government installed in Kamakura by the Ashikaga Shogunate but the relationship between the Ashikaga Shogunate and this regional government deteriorated later).

sen.j: 古河公方足利成氏からの働きかけで義藤が一揆蜂起の支援をした可能性は無いとは言えない。
sen.e: There was possibility that Yoshifuji helped the uprising under an influence from Koga kubo (descendants of one of the Ashikaga families that held the office of the Kanto district administrator).

There was a possibility that Yoshifuji helped the uprising because Shigeuji ASHIKAGA, Koga kubo, a branch family of the Ashikaga clan that was in charge of the Kamakura Government, might have asked Yoshifuji to help the uprising.
sen.cmt: 「足利成氏」の名前が抜けています。
sen.e: There was a possibility that Yoshifuji helped the uprising because Shigeuji ASHIKAGA, Koga kubo, a branch family of the Ashikaga clan that was in charge of the Kamakura Government, might have asked Yoshifuji to help the uprising.

sen.j: 同年12月20日、将軍足利義政の妻日野富子が足利義尚を出産すると、義藤は将軍御所へ参上し、御祝い言上と太刀一振りを進上した。
sen.e: In December, 1465, when Tomiko HINO, a wife of Shogun Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA gave birth to a baby, Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA, he visited Shogun's place and offered congratulations and demonstration using a sword.
When Tomiko HINO, wife of the Shogun Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA gave birth to a baby in December 20, 1465, Yoshifuji visited the Shogun's place and presented one sword with a congratulatory address.
sen.cmt: 正確性に問題があります。
sen.e: When Tomiko HINO, wife of the Shogun Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA gave birth to Yoshihisa ASHIKAGA in December 20, 1465, Yoshifuji visited the Shogun's place and presented one sword with a congratulatory address.

sen.j: 更に翌日、西条吉良氏（上吉良）の当主吉良義真と揃って伊勢貞親邸を訪れ、将軍への取次ぎの礼を述べている（『親元日記』）。
sen.e: In addition, the next day, he visited the residence of Sadachika ISE with Yoshizane KIRA, the head of the Saijokira clan and expressed his gratitude for his acting as a middleman to Shogun ("Chikamoto Nikki" [Chikamoto's diary]).

In addition, the next day, he visited the residence of Sadachika ISE with Yoshizane KIRA, the head of the Saijokira clan and expressed his gratitude for his acting as a middleman to Shogun ("Chikamoto Nikki" [Chikamoto's diary]).

In addition, the next day, he visited the residence of Sadachika ISE with Yoshizane KIRA, the head of the Saijokira clan and expressed his gratitude for his acting as a middleman to Shogun ("Chikamoto Nikki" [Chikamoto's diary]).

sen.j: 応仁元年（1467年）正月、応仁の乱が始まると、義藤は義理の父である山名宗全の率いる西軍に味方した。
sen.e: In February, 1467, when Onin War broke out, Yoshifuji sided with the West Camp headed by his father-in-law, Sozen YAMANA.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In February, 1467, when Onin War broke out, Yoshifuji sided with the West Camp headed by his father-in-law, Sozen YAMANA.
In February, 1467, when Onin War broke out, Yoshifuji sided with the West Camp headed by his father-in-law, Sozen YAMANA.

sen.j: 東軍に味方した吉良義真に先んじて三河へ下向、西条吉良氏の領地へ攻撃を開始したらしい。
sen.e: It was likely that he got a head start and went to Mikawa Province ahead of Yoshimasa KIRA who sided with the East Camp and then, started to attack on the territory of the Saijokira clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was likely that he got a head start and went to Mikawa Province ahead of Yoshizane KIRA who sided with the East Camp and then, started to attack on the territory of the Saijokira clan.
It was likely that he got a head start and went to Mikawa Province ahead of Yoshizane KIRA who sided with the East Camp and then, started to attack on the territory of the Saijokira clan.

sen.j: 義真はやや遅れて同年5月18日に三河へ下向する（『大乗院寺社雑事記』）。
sen.e: On June 28, 1467, Yoshimasa started to go down south to Mikawa Province slightly later than Yoshifuji ("Daijoin jisha zojiki" [Miscellaneous Records of the Daijo Temple and Shrine]).
On June 28, 1467, Yoshizane started to go down south to Mikawa Province slightly later than Yoshifuji ("Daijoin jisha zojiki" [Miscellaneous Records of the Daijo Temple and Shrine]).
On June 28, 1467, Yoshizane started to go down south to Mikawa Province slightly later than Yoshifuji ("Daijoin jisha zojiki" [Miscellaneous Records of the Daijo Temple and Shrine]).

sen.j: 三河での東西両吉良氏の戦いの様子は史料が無く判然としない。
sen.e: There was no historical material about how the East and West Camps of KIRA clan fought in the battle in Mikawa Province, so, how they fought has been unknown.
There was no historical material about how the East and West Camps of KIRA clan fought in the battle in Mikawa Province, so, how they fought has been unknown.
There was no historical material about how the East and West Camps of KIRA clan fought in the battle in Mikawa Province, so, how they fought has been unknown.

sen.j: 僅かに『三河軍記』（嘉永6年（1853年）成立）がその模様を伝えるが、内容は誤謬が多く信頼できない。
sen.e: "Mikawa gunki" (military records of Mikawa Province compiled in 1853) slightly showed how the battle was fought, but there were a lot of fallacies in it, so, it was not reliable.
Only "Mikawa gunki" (military records of Mikawa Province compiled in 1853) reports on the battle, but the book is not reliable having many inaccurate descriptions in it.
Only "Mikawa gunki" (military records of Mikawa Province compiled in 1853) reports on the battle, but the book is not reliable having many inaccurate descriptions in it.

sen.j: 西条吉良氏の吉良義真は文明 (日本)11年（1479年）頃まで三河に留まり、同年9月頃上洛したらしい。
sen.e: It was likely that Yoshimasa KIRA, the Saijokira clan stayed in Mikawa Province until around 1479, and then around September in the same year, he went to Kyoto.
It was likely that Yoshizane KIRA, the Saijokira clan, stayed in Mikawa Province until around 1479, and then around September in the same year he went to Kyoto.
It was likely that Yoshizane KIRA, the Saijokira clan, stayed in Mikawa Province until around 1479, and then around September in the same year he went to Kyoto.

sen.j: 東条吉良氏と同じ西軍に属する一色義直軍が三河で優勢であったためと思われる（一色義直は文明10年（1478年）に至りようやく三河を放棄する旨、文書で表明し軍を撤収した）。
sen.e: That was probably because Yoshinao ISSHIKI who belonged to the West Camp, where the Tojokira clan also belonged, was prevailing in the Mikawa Province (in 1478, Yoshinao ISSHIKI finally issued the document that expressed he abandoned Mikawa Province and retreated).

That was probably because Yoshinao ISSHIKI who belonged to the West Camp, where the Tojokira clan also belonged, was prevailing in the Mikawa Province (in 1478, Yoshinao ISSHIKI finally issued the document that expressed he abandoned Mikawa Province and retreated).

That was probably because Yoshinao ISSHIKI who belonged to the West Camp, where the Tojokira clan also belonged, was prevailing in the Mikawa Province (in 1478, Yoshinao ISSHIKI finally issued the document that expressed he abandoned Mikawa Province and retreated).

sen.j: 義藤の最期について、『西尾町史』は西条吉良氏の領地に攻め込んだが、義真に迎撃され敗軍となり、上方へ逃走し消息不明となったとする。
sen.e: As for Yoshifuji's last moments, "Nishio choshi" (the history of Nishio cho) said that he attacked on the territory of the Saijokira clan, but he sustained counterattacks by Yoshisada and was defeated, and then ran away to the Kyoto-Osaka area and vanished.

As for Yoshifuji's last moments, "Nishio choshi" (the history of Nishio cho) said that he attacked on the territory of the Saijokira clan, but he sustained counterattacks by Yoshizane and was defeated, and then ran away to the Kyoto-Osaka area and vanished.

As for Yoshifuji's last moments, "Nishio choshi" (the history of Nishio cho) said that he attacked on the territory of the Saijokira clan, but he sustained counterattacks by Yoshizane and was defeated, and then ran away to the Kyoto-Osaka area and vanished.

sen.j: 一方『三河軍記』は西条吉良氏と和睦し、晩年になって一子（持清）を授かり、程なくして病死。
sen.e: On the other hand, "Mikawa gunki" mentioned that he became reconciled with the Saijokira clan and later in life, he had a child (Mochikiyo) and soon, he died.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, "Mikawa gunki" mentioned that he became reconciled with the Saijokira clan and later in life, he had a child (Mochikiyo) and soon, he died.
On the other hand, "Mikawa gunki" mentioned that he became reconciled with the Saijokira clan and later in life, he had a child (Mochikiyo) and soon, he died.

sen.j: 幼少の持清を青野松平氏の松平義春が後見したとする。
sen.e: Yoshiharu MATSUDAIRA of the Aono Matsudaira clan acted as a guardian for little Mochikiyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Yoshiharu MATSUDAIRA of the Aono Matsudaira clan acted as a guardian for little Mochikiyo.
Yoshiharu MATSUDAIRA of the Aono Matsudaira clan acted as a guardian for little Mochikiyo.

sen.j: 義藤が逃亡せねばならないような大きな戦いがあったという記録は同時代史料には全く見当たらない。
sen.e: There is no record in any historical materials in that period that a big battle broke out and Yoshifuji had to run away.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is no record in any historical materials in that period that a big battle broke out and Yoshifuji had to run away.
There is no record in any historical materials in that period that a big battle broke out and Yoshifuji had to run away.

sen.j: もし、義藤が敗走したなら、当然攻め込まれたであろう東条城の跡からも合戦の痕跡は見つかっていない。
sen.e: If Yoshifuji had suffered a rout, there must have been traces of the battle in Tojo-jo Castle which must have been attacked.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If Yoshifuji had suffered a rout, there must have been traces of the battle in Tojo-jo Castle which must have been attacked.
If Yoshifuji had suffered a rout, there must have been traces of the battle in Tojo-jo Castle which must have been attacked.

sen.j: 幾度か合戦にはなったものの、当主が他国へ逃走せねばならないような規模とはならず、京都の東西両軍の和睦（文明9年（1477年））を受けて東西両吉良氏も和睦をしたのではないか。
sen.e: It is said that there were several battles, but they were not big enough for the heads of the castle to escape and given the reconciliation of the East and West Camps, the East and West of Kira clans became reconciled to each other.

It can be said that although there were several battles, there was no battle that was large enough that the head of the clan had to run away and following the reconciliation of the East camp and the West camp in Kyoto (1477), Yoshifuji of the Tojokira clan and Yoshizane of the Saijokira clan also reconciled.

It can be said that although there were several battles, there was no battle that was large enough that the head of the clan had to run away and following the reconciliation of the East camp and the West camp in Kyoto (1477), Yoshifuji of the Tojokira clan and Yoshizane of the Saijokira clan also reconciled.

sen.j: 松平氏の後見の部分は信用できないが、大筋において『三河軍記』のような結末に至ったと思われる。
sen.e: The part of the story indicating that the Matsudaira clan acted as a guardian for little Mochikiyo was not reliable, but in broad outline, his life may end as the story of "Mikawa gunki" suggested.
The part of the story indicating that the Matsudaira clan acted as a guardian for little Mochikiyo was not reliable, but in broad outline, his life may end as the story of "Mikawa gunki" suggested.
The part of the story indicating that the Matsudaira clan acted as a guardian for little Mochikiyo was not reliable, but in broad outline, his life may end as the story of "Mikawa gunki" suggested.

sen.j: 義藤の没年月日は不明。
sen.e: Yoshifuji's age at death was unknown.
Yoshifuji's age at death was unknown.
Yoshifuji's age at death was unknown.

sen.j: 法名は亀蔵寺殿。
sen.e: His homyo (a posthumous Buddhist name) was kamezojiden.
sen.cmt: 亀蔵寺殿の読み方不明のため、kamwzojidenとしました。
sen.e: His homyo (a posthumous Buddhist name) was kamezojiden.
His homyo (a posthumous Buddhist name) was kamezojiden.
